paragraphs.text: How I Founded a $2 Billion Company with a 95 Cent Book from RadioShack
Those were my peeps. We used to walk around with either a Radio Shack projects book, an Isaac Asimov novel, or both :)
paragraphs.name: 47f3

711f4fc05ede.title: That’s a good point, AI is certainly going to continue growing in relevance and application.

paragraphs.text: That’s a good point, AI is certainly going to continue growing in relevance and application. Two things that will keep slowing its advance in human engagement, though, are time — both processing and latency — and the limitations of the physical interface (which is where that Radio Shack book came in handy). The latter is a big deal because humans are…

paragraphs.name: 653d

paragraphs.text: Oh, I get that. I think a lot of us are struggling to keep a balanced view given the current political, ah, “situation.”

Incidentally, we didn’t have any idea how far Polycom would go, back then, we just knew what we were trying to do and worked to do it the absolute best that we could. It started with design and engineering…

paragraphs.text: An interesting parallel! Both encourage creativity through a rich environment (although I don’t recall that RadioShack offered free beer as WeWork does) and an opportunity for chance encounters with other curious, often driven, people.
paragraphs.name: b4b9

d6cf159bad68.title: Really nicely written, Steve. I’m glad the main points got through, I always wonder. Thanks!

paragraphs.text: Really nicely written, Steve. I’m glad the main points got through, I always wonder. Thanks!

7ad71b418e1d.title: In the office at 6AM sounds so like you, Marc.

paragraphs.text: In the office at 6AM sounds so like you, Marc. And it explains why that bottle looked about a half-millilitre low to me when I breezed in later that day. Thanks for the story!
paragraphs.name: db98

paragraphs.text: Thank you.

Great article, very inspiring.…..and a great product too. When I was running difficult international projects I found getting people round a phone, wherever they were, really helped us all stay on the same page. We had video conferencing, but I found sound worked better. Less distracting so we could listen more…

34996905a925.title: Yep, I should have followed my instinct and assumed otherwise.

paragraphs.text: Yep, I should have followed my instinct and assumed otherwise. Wired‘s wording was this: “…TRS-80, one of the first affordable personal computers and one of the first devices RadioShack ever produced. … John Draper, the phone phreaker known as “Captain Crunch,” hacked his way into free long-distance calls using a Touch Tone dialer he bought from…

virtuals.subtitle: Woz bought one too, and he says it cost him a fortune. He used it for the now-infamous Blue Box”

content.subtitle: Woz bought one too, and he says it cost him a fortune. He used it for the now-infamous Blue Box”

paragraphs.text: I bought that same book. Built my own sub-woofer for my Firebird…awesome bass, different outcome. Nice story!
paragraphs.name: 920c

848ce33231a2.title: Note that the bit about Woz and Jobs’ blue box incorporating a TRS-80 is inaccurate; Radio Shack…

paragraphs.text: Note that the bit about Woz and Jobs’ blue box incorporating a TRS-80 is inaccurate; Radio Shack was not yet in the computer business at that point. (The Steves shipped a personal computer before the Shack did.)
paragraphs.name: 6de2

cdc200106446.title: There are so many things about this article that are beautiful — both nostalgic and inspiring.

paragraphs.text: There are so many things about this article that are beautiful — both nostalgic and inspiring. Radio Shack certainly was a place where walking the aisles actually generated the possibility that anyone with the desire to learn could create something potentially useful. I remember in early high school, before even knowing that there was such a thing as…
paragraphs.name: 14b7

d6d16b5c2554.title: I fucking hate it when people write these click bait headlines.

paragraphs.text: I fucking hate it when people write these click bait headlines. You write this as if this book was the root cause of you becoming a billionaire. Give me a break. It is like saying, “I didn’t know how to join these two pieces of wire together. Suddenly I saw a soldering manual and I was able to do it and now I’m a billionaire.” Or, titling your piece…
paragraphs.name: df3f

virtuals.subtitle: Congratulations on making a shitload of money.

content.subtitle: Congratulations on making a shitload of money.

46cb5b5e0faa.title: Excellent article. Congratulations on all your success!

paragraphs.text: Excellent article. Congratulations on all your success!
paragraphs.name: a705

29730eff4c86.title: Inspiring read, interesting how you note that Radioshack was a hub of creativity.

paragraphs.text: Inspiring read, interesting how you note that Radioshack was a hub of creativity. I feel its very akin to the WeWork’s of the world today.
paragraphs.name: 6bd4

86aa1f3b5904.title: All through grade 5, my teacher let me draw spaceships instead of notes.

paragraphs.text: All through grade 5, my teacher let me draw spaceships instead of notes. I suspect there are still teachers like these around, but they don’t want to be highlighted. Academia is not unlike the Inquisition in some ways.
paragraphs.name: 46d3

7d4120e936b0.title: Bish — Wow, sorry you took it that way.

paragraphs.text: Bish — Wow, sorry you took it that way. The title was intended to draw interest but I don’t think it’s clickbait. It’s accurate in what it says — the company started “with” the book, not “because of” the book. The book saved us time, though, and added confidence to that path of speaker exploration.
paragraphs.name: 42b7
